page.title: 10FARMING IN BEDGEBURY AREA
page.content: Farming in the High Weald is not easy or high-yielding. The reason is partly low-fertility soil derived from sand rock and partly the banks and gullies left by water erosion. The area is made beautiful by oaks and beeches which denote deep well drained earth; unfortunately the good places are patchy and this does not make for fields of evenly growing crops. There has always been dairying but it is declining due to over-supply of milk in Europe. Sheep have largely replaced cows: the resulting well kept hedges and fences are good to see. Traditionally hops have been important in the area, growing well in the sheltered valleys. Now, however, rationalisation of the industry has made many small oasthouses redundant, some being converted into homes which happily retain the unique cowls.
